newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean won ends down, central bank sells dollars.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean won ends down, central bank sells dollars.

text.p: The won closed weakens on Monday on stop-loss dollar buying, but its fall was limited by the central bank's repeated dollar sales, dealers said.
Dealers said the local currency was expected to gain momentum on month-end dollar supply from exporters and a rising dollar inflow for equity investment.
The won closed at 981.40, down from the previous closing at 890.40 on Friday.
The Bank of Korea was seen selling dollars at around 892 won in mid-afternoon and again at around 891.20 won later.
Bank of Korea officials were unavailable for comment.
Dealers said the intervention appeared aimed at keeping the won from falling sharply in the aftermath of the recent plunges of Thai and Philippine currencies vis-a-vis the U.S. unit.

"Traders were growing nervous following the news on the baht and peso, and sentiment for the dollar was gaining strength here," said a foreign bank dealer. "The central bank's intervention was necessary to ease such anxiety."
Dealers forecast the won's base mid-rate was likely to be pegged at 891.40 won on Tuesday, against 890.00 won on Monday.
